Award.AwardTitle: Multifunctional Hybrid Porous Nanoparticles for Controlled Drug Release
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1207019 PI: Weiss, Sharon ORG: Vanderbilt University

Title: Multifunctional Hybrid Porous Nanoparticles for Controlled Drug Release

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Porous silicon (PSi) is a promising drug delivery vehicle owing to its tunable porosity, biocompatibility, biodegradability, and exceptionally large specific surface area, which can be exploited for drug loading and controlled release. Unlike liposomal or micellar drug delivery vehicles, PSi can be fabricated into a vast range of sizes and shapes by an imprinting technique recently developed by the PI. The aim of this proposal is to explore multifunctional porous micro- and nanoparticles for the treatment of localized pathologies. The specific objectives of the research are: (1) understanding the impact of porous silicon particle (PSP) shape and size on cellular uptake and selectivity, (2) investigating smart surface attachment chemistries to enable intracellular, site-specific release of loaded therapeutic peptides, and (3) exploring the viability of an ultrasonically-induced drug release mechanism and piezoelectric-functionalized PSPs.

BROADER IMPACTS: This research combines scientific and engineering methods of the complementary disciplines of materials science, biomedical engineering, electrical engineering, and physics for the realization of a drug delivery platform capable of combating some of the most socially and economically devastating medical conditions. The integrated educational goals of the plan involve the exposure of participating graduate and undergraduate researchers to the interdisciplinary nature of nanoscience and a team-based research atmosphere. Member selection of the research team will emphasize increasing the participation of gender and ethnic minorities, as facilitated through coordination with the existing NSF-sponsored Vanderbilt-Fisk-Delaware State I-cubed program in materials science, the Vanderbilt Institute of Nanoscale Science and Engineering REU program, and the Vanderbilt chapters of SWE, NSBE, and SHPE. Educational K-12 outreach will focus upon the development of inquiry-based learning activities to teach nanoscience concepts, to be shared during school visits and events at the Nashville Adventure Science Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The overarching goal of this project was to investigate multifunctional porous nanoparticles for use in targeted drug delivery and controlled release of therapeutic drug molecules. During the program, significant contributions were made in (1) understanding efficient drug loading and release mechanisms in the porous nanoparticles, (2) understanding how smart polymer coatings on the porous nanoparticles affect cellular uptake and intracellular drug release, and (3) exploring methods to fabricate porous nanoparticles hybridized with zinc oxide, a piezoelectric material that could enable ultrasonically-induced drug release. Porous silicon nanoparticles have a large internal surface area into which drugs can be loaded, and the material is biocompatible. This program found that porous silicon nanoparticles are very well-suited for delivery of peptide nucleic acid molecules that comprise a new class of therapeutics that faces significant translational challenges due to its poor intracellular activity without an appropriate delivery vehicle. Using a pH-responsive smart polymer coating, peptide nucleic acid loaded porous silicon nanoparticles were demonstrated to efficiently inhibit a liver-specific micro-RNA involved in cholesterol synthesis. Inhibition of this micro-RNA is a promising therapeutic approach for lowering elevated cholesterol levels. This program also demonstrated different methods of functionalizing zinc oxide to porous silicon films and nanoparticles, including sol-gel, sputtering, and electrochemical deposition, and showed piezoresponsive behavior of the hybrid materials. The results of this program have been disseminated through oral and poster presentations at a variety of scientific forums, including both national and regional conferences. In addition, this work has been published in high-impact, peer reviewed scientific journals.

Broader Impacts: This research project yielded a new nanocomposite peptide nucleic acid therapeutic delivery vehicle proven to overcome both systemic and intracellular delivery barriers. Based on their high bioavailability and long blood circulation half-life, porous silicon nanoparticles coated with a smart polymer have the potential to effectively facilitate the delivery of a broad range of therapeutic and diagnostic payloads. Students involved in this project were exposed to interdisciplinary research in the fields of material science, biomedical engineering, chemistry, electrical engineering, and medicine.  Three graduate students and four undergraduate students contributed to different aspects of the project; four of these students are members of under-represented groups in STEM. During every year of the program, project participants engaged in outreach to help make members of society (especially the younger generation) aware of the importance of STEM. Examples of hands-on activities carried out during the program include demonstrations for a diverse group of students in the Governor's School on Emerging Technologies, the Vanderbilt Summer Academy, and Harpeth Hall.
